_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Procedures.



SAL Chemical is an ISO 9000 - 2018 certified company and an approved CFATS facility by the Department of Homeland Security.  In addition, we are committed to continuous improvement through the chemical industry's Responsible Distribution Program (RD) through the National Association of Chemical Distributors.  



As part of our Quality Assurance, CFATs and RD commitments, we make health, safety and environmental considerations a priority in our planning for all existing and new operations, products, processes and facilities.  



We have had ZERO reportable releases in the previous 5 years.



Description of the Facility and Regulated Substances.  



SAL Chemical's operations include warehousing, repackaging, and distribution of municipal and industrial type chemicals.  SAL Chemical maintains an inventory of chlorine that exceeds the EPA's threshold.  



SAL may have up to 51,000# of chlorine stored outdoors in both 2000# and 150# cylinders.  Maximum inventory of 70% HF will 5,000#. These products are NOT repackaged; they are stored, inventoried, and shipped to the customer in the original containers.  



The chlorine storage and distribution operation is regulated by OSHA's PSM rule and therefore is a Program 3 process.  The worst case release of chlorine at the facility would be a catastrophic release of 2000# of chlorine from a one ton container over a 10 minute period.  The extent of the release was calculated without taking credit for any mitigating factors, which are in accordance with EPA requirements for calculation the effects of a worst case release.  The distance to the toxic endpoint of .0087 mg/L is 1.3 miles, which would potentially impact a residential population of 2700.  EPA's model RMPComp was used in estimating the distance to the toxic endpoint.  The US census bureau internet site was used to determine the population.



The alternative release scenario for chlorine is a one t

on container leak from a one half inch diameter hole, resulting in a leak of 34 pounds per minute of liquid chlorine.  It is estimated that the leak could continue for 60 minutes before being stopped.  Although unlikely to occur, this release scenario is more likely to occur than the worst case scenario described above.  This release would be mitigated by Sal Chemical's storage and inspection programs.  The containers are stored away from vehicular traffic, and the containers are inspected daily.  The distance to the toxic endpoint for this scenario is .1 mile, which would not reach a public receptor.  The release rate was derived from EPA's RMP guidance for wastewater treatment plants, and the distance to the toxic endpoint was calculated using RMP Comp.  The residential population was estimated from the US census bureau's internet site.  





HF storage is a program 1.  A worst case release of HF would be 350# released inside a 10,000 Foot building.  The release rate to the outside air is .21 pounds per minute.  The distance to the toxic endpoint of .016mg/L for this release is .1 mile, which would not reach a public receptor.  The distance to the toxic endpoint was estimated using EPA's RMPComp model and the population data was assessed from the US census bureau's internet database.    







General accidental release prevention program and chemical specific prevention steps.  



SAL is an active member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD) and applies the NACD's strict principals for safe distribution of chemical.  Sal Chemical also uses elements of an OSHA PSM program for chlorine operations.  The PSM program contains 12 elements, including a hazard analysis, standard operating procedures, employee training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and management of change. In addition to the PSM program, Jason Mattern, our Quality and Regulatory Compliance Manager, gives an annual training on the safe handling and storage of Chlori

ne.  JasonA?s training program is certified in the state of Ohio to award 2 hours of Continuing Education Credits.  



Annually, the Weirton Fire Department tours our facility for review and critique.  Jason is also a 20 year member of the Hancock County LEPC and is currently serving the elected position of Secretary.



Five Year Accident History.  



SAL Chemical has had no accidental releases of any chemical in the past 5 years.



Emergency Response Program.  



SAL Chemical maintains, and coordinates a written Emergency Action Plan with both the Brooke and Hancock County LEPC and Weirton Fire Department.  This EAP describes escape measures, procedures, rescue and medical duties and information on reporting requirements.  We also have an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) which supplements our commitment to public, employee and environmental safety.



Planned changes to improve safety.  



SAL Chemical plans to continue its membership in the NACD and uphold the NACD's principles for safe and chemical distribution.  SAL Chemical will also continue providing training to its employees on the safe handling of regulated substances.  Our health and safety manual was reviewed and integrated into our ICP plan in July 2019.  SAL Chemical is also regulated by the State of West Virginia because several Above Ground Storage Tanks are used at our facility.  These ASTs were just re-certified and approved by a 3rd party for another 3 year cycle.
